facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 31 of 1953 in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: On 6th April 1951, appellant transported 15 maunds of juwar from village Khanjroli to Mandvi without a permit.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the appellant was that on 6th April, 1951, he had transported 15 maunds of juwar from his village of Khanjroli to Mandvi without a permit,

facts.text: Resident First Class Magistrate of Bardoli tried the case and found appellant guilty.

anchor.surface_text: The Resident First Class Magistrate of Bardoli who tried the case found him guilty, and sentenced him to imprisonment till the rising of the Court and a fine

facts.text: Sentenced to imprisonment till the rising of the Court and fine of Rs. 500.

issues.text: whether contravention of section 5 1 of the Bombay Food Grains Regulation of Movement and Sale Order, 1949, is punishable under section 2 of the Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947, in which case the trial by the Resident First Class Magistrate would be without jurisdiction or whether it is punishable under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, as amended by Act No. LII of 1950, in which case, the trial and conviction of the appellant by that Magistrate would be perfectly legal

anchor.surface_text: and the point for determination is whether contravention of section 5 1 of the Bombay Food Grains Regulation of Movement and Sale Order, 1949, is punishable under section 2 of the Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947, in which case the trial by the Resident First Class Magistrate would be without jurisdiction or whether it is punishable under section 7 of the

issues.text: whether the amendments made to the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act by the Central Legislature in 1948, 1949 and 1950 are furthers legislation falling within section 107 2 of the Government of India Act or law with respect to the same matter falling within article 254 2

anchor.surface_text: Then the only question to be decided is whether the amendments made to the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act by the Central Legislature in 1948, 1949 and 1950 are furthers legislation falling within section 107 2 of the Government of India Act or law with respect to the same matter falling within article 254 2 . The important thing to consider with reference to this provision is whether the legislation is in respect of the same matter.

issues.text: what is the subject-matter of the Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947?

anchor.surface_text: Considering the matter from this standpoint, the first question to be asked is, what is the subject-matter of the Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947? The preamble recites that it was to provide for the enhancement of penalties for contravention of orders made under the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946.

issues.text: what is the scope of the subsequent legislation in 1948, 1949 and 1950 ?

anchor.surface_text: Then the next question is, what is the scope of the subsequent legislation in 1948, 1949 and 1950 ? As the offence for which the appellant has been convicted was committed on 6th April, 1951, it would be sufficient for the purpose of the present appeal to consider the effect of Act No. LII of 1950, which was in force on that date.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that section 2 of Bombay Act No. XXXVI of 1947 cannot prevail as against section 7 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act No. XXIV of 1946 as amended by Act No. LII of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, entirely in agreement with the opinion of Chagla J. and Chainani J. that Act No. LII of 1950 is a legislation in respect of the same matter as Act No. XXXVI of 1947.
